English_Hadith: Narrated Mughirah ibn Shu'bah: When the Prophet (ﷺ) went (outside) to relieve himself, he went to a far-off place.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Mughirah ibn Shu'bah emphasizes the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) adherence to proper hygiene and modesty. It highlights his practice of going to a secluded place when relieving himself, demonstrating his respect for personal privacy and avoiding any potential discomfort or embarrassment to others. This practice aligns with Islamic teachings that encourage cleanliness and modesty in all aspects of life.

English_Hadith: Narrated Jabir ibn Abdullah: When the Prophet (ﷺ) felt the need of relieving himself, he went far off where no one could see him.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Jabir ibn Abdullah further reinforces the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) commitment to modesty and personal hygiene. It emphasizes his practice of going to a secluded location when relieving himself, avoiding any unnecessary exposure or discomfort to others. This behavior is consistent with Islamic teachings that promote cleanliness and respect for personal privacy.

English_Hadith: Abu al-Tayyah reported on the authority of a shaykh (an old man): When Abdullah ibn Abbas came to Basrah, people narrated to him traditions from AbuMusa.Therefore Ibn Abbas wrote to him asking him about certain things.In reply AbuMusa wrote to him saying: One day I was in the company of the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ).He wanted to urinate.Then he came to a soft ground at the foot of a wall and urinated.He (the Prophet) then said: If any of you wants to urinate, he should look for a place (like this) for his urination.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith describes a situation where the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) sought a secluded, soft spot at the base of a wall to relieve himself. He then encouraged others to find similar suitable locations when necessary, emphasizing the importance of both privacy and potentially choosing softer ground for comfort.

English_Hadith: Anas b. Malik reported: When the Apostle of Allaah (sal Allahu alayhi wa sallam) entered the toilet, he used to say (before entering): "O Allaah, I seek refuge in Thee." This is according to the version of Hammad. 'Abd al-Warith has another version :"I seek refuge in Allaah from male and female devils."
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith highlights the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) practice of seeking refuge in Allah (SWT) before entering the toilet, demonstrating his awareness of potential spiritual impurities and his reliance on divine protection. The different versions suggest variations in the specific wording of the supplication, both emphasizing the intent to seek refuge from harmful influences.

English_Hadith: Another tradition on the authority of Anas has: " O Allaah, I seek refuge in Thee."Shu'bah said: Anas sometimes reported the words: "I take refuge in Allah."
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith further reinforces the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) practice of seeking refuge in Allah (SWT) before entering the toilet. The variations in the specific wording of the supplication, as reported by different narrators, highlight the flexibility and personal preference in the choice of supplications. The underlying theme remains consistent: seeking divine protection and guidance in all aspects of life.

English_Hadith: Narrated Zayd ibn Arqam: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: These privies are frequented by the jinns and devils.So when anyone amongst you goes there, he should say: "I seek refuge in Allah from male and female devils."
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith explains the importance of saying a supplication for protection before entering the toilet. Prophet Muhammad (PBUH) warned that these places are frequented by jinn and devils. The supplication, "I seek refuge in Allah from male and female devils," serves as a way to seek Allah's protection from any potential harm or spiritual impurity in these areas.

English_Hadith: Narrated Salman al-Farsi: It was said to Salman: Your Prophet teaches you everything, even about excrement. He replied: Yes. He has forbidden us to face the qiblah at the time of easing or urinating, and cleansing with right hand, and cleansing with less than three stones, or cleansing with dung or bone.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Salman al-Farsi highlights the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) guidance on matters of hygiene and etiquette, even those considered mundane. It outlines specific instructions regarding toilet practices, such as avoiding facing the Qiblah during urination or defecation, using the right hand for cleansing, using a minimum of three stones for cleansing, and avoiding the use of dung or bone for this purpose. These guidelines reflect the Prophet's emphasis on cleanliness, modesty, and respect for the sanctity of religious practices.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Hurairah: The Apostle of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) as saying: I am like father to you. When any of you goes to privy, he should not face or turn his back towards the qiblah. He should not cleanse with his right hand. He (the Prophet, sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam) also commanded the Muslims to use three stones and forbade them to use dung or decayed bone.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Abu Hurairah reinforces the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) guidance on proper toilet etiquette. It emphasizes the importance of avoiding facing or turning away from the Qiblah during urination or defecation, using the left hand for cleansing, and using a minimum of three stones for cleansing while avoiding the use of dung or decayed bone. These guidelines reflect the Prophet's concern for cleanliness, modesty, and respect for religious practices.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Ayyub : That he (the Holy Prophet, sal Allahu alayhi wa sallam) said:"When you go to the privy, neither turn your face nor your back towards the qiblah at the time of excretion or urination, but turn towards the east or the west. (Abu Ayyub said): When we came to Syria, we found that the toilets already built there were facing the qiblah, We turned our faces away from them and begged pardon of Allaah.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Abu Ayyub further reinforces the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) guidance on toilet etiquette. It specifically instructs Muslims to avoid facing or turning away from the Qiblah during urination or defecation, instead turning towards the east or west. Abu Ayyub's experience in Syria highlights the importance of adhering to this guidance even in unfamiliar environments, as he and his companions adjusted their toilet practices to avoid facing the Qiblah. This demonstrates their commitment to following the Prophet's teachings and their understanding of the significance of respecting the Qiblah.

English_Hadith: Narrated Ma'qil ibn AbuMa'qil al-Asadi: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) has forbidden us to face the two qiblahs at the time of urination or excretion.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Ma'qil ibn AbuMa'qil al-Asadi reinforces the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) guidance on toilet etiquette. It specifically prohibits facing either of the two Qiblahs (the original Qiblah of Jerusalem and the current Qiblah of Mecca) during urination or defecation. This instruction demonstrates the Prophet's emphasis on respecting the sanctity of the Qiblah and maintaining a sense of reverence even in personal matters.

English_Hadith: Marwan al-Asfar said: I saw Ibn Umar make his camel kneel down facing the qiblah, then he sat down urinating in its direction. So I said: AbuAbdurRahman, has this not been forbidden? He replied: Why not, that was forbidden only in open country; but when there is something between you and the qiblah that conceals you , then there is no harm.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Marwan al-Asfar highlights a specific circumstance regarding toilet etiquette. It describes Ibn Umar's practice of urinating while facing the Qiblah, which was generally forbidden. However, Ibn Umar justified his action by explaining that the prohibition applies only in open areas where there is no physical barrier between the person and the Qiblah. In situations where there is something that conceals the person from the Qiblah, such as a camel, the prohibition does not apply. This clarifies a potential exception to the general rule of avoiding facing the Qiblah during urination or defecation, demonstrating the importance of understanding the nuances of Islamic teachings and their application in different contexts.

English_Hadith: Narrated 'Abd Allaah b. 'Umar : I ascended the roof of the house and saw the Apostle of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam) sitting on two bricks facing Jerusalem (Bait al-Maqdis) for relieving himself.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by 'Abd Allaah b. 'Umar describes a specific instance where the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) relieved himself while facing Jerusalem, which was the original Qiblah before the direction was changed to Mecca. This suggests that the prohibition against facing the Qiblah during urination or defecation was not strictly enforced in all circumstances, particularly in private settings. However, it's important to note that this specific instance does not contradict the general guidance provided in other hadiths regarding avoiding the Qiblah during these activities.

English_Hadith: Narrated Jabir ibn Abdullah: The Prophet of Allah (ﷺ) forbade us to face the qiblah at the time of making water.Then I saw him facing it (qiblah) urinating or easing himself one year before his death.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Jabir ibn Abdullah initially states that the Prophet Muhammad (peace be upon him) forbade Muslims from facing the Qiblah during urination or defecation. However, it later mentions a specific instance where the Prophet himself was observed facing the Qiblah while relieving himself. This suggests that the prohibition might not have been strictly enforced in all circumstances, possibly due to specific situations or personal preferences. The overall guidance remains consistent, emphasizing the importance of respecting the Qiblah and maintaining a sense of reverence even in personal matters.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abdullah ibn Umar: When the Prophet (ﷺ) wanted to relieve himself, he would not raise his garment, until he lowered himself near the ground.Abu DAwud said: This tradition has been transmitted by 'Abd al-Salam b. Harb on the authority of al-A'mash from Anas b. Malik. This chain of narrators is weak (because A'mash's hearing tradition from Anas b. Malik is not established).
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Abdullah ibn Umar describes the Prophet Muhammad's (peace be upon him) practice of not raising his garment until he was close to the ground when relieving himself. However, the chain of narrators for this tradition is considered weak, as there is uncertainty about the reliability of al-A'mash's transmission from Anas ibn Malik. While this hadith may not be considered as strong evidence, it provides insight into potential practices related to modesty and hygiene.

English_Hadith: Narrated AbuSa'id al-Khudri: I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) say: When two persons go together for relieving themselves uncovering their private parts and talking together, Allah, the Great and Majestic, becomes wrathful at this (action).Abu Dawud said: This tradition has been narrated only by 'Ikrimah b. 'Ammar.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Abu Sa'id al-Khudri emphasizes the importance of modesty and respect for personal privacy, particularly when relieving oneself. It warns that Allah (SWT) becomes displeased when two people uncover their private parts and engage in conversation while doing so. The tradition also highlights the potential negative consequences of disregarding these principles. While the chain of narrators for this hadith is relatively short, it provides valuable guidance on proper behavior and conduct.

English_Hadith: Narrated Ibn 'Umar : A man passed by the Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) while he was urinating, and saluted him. The Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam) did not return the salutation to him.Abu Dawud said : It is narrated on the authority of Ibn 'Umar that theProphet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam) performed tayammum, then he returned the salutation to the man.
Hadith_Expalation: The hadith narrated by Ibn 'Umar highlights the importance of modesty and respect for personal privacy, even in situations that may seem trivial. It describes an instance where a man greeted the Prophet (peace be upon him) while he was urinating, and the Prophet did not respond to the salutation. However, the Prophet later performed tayammum (dry ablution) and then returned the salutation, suggesting that the initial omission was due to the sensitivity of the situation and the Prophet's desire to maintain modesty. This incident serves as a reminder of the importance of considering the context and appropriateness of actions, even in everyday situations.

English_Hadith: Narrated Muhajir ibn Qunfudh: Muhajir came to the Prophet (ﷺ) while he was urinating. He saluted him. The Prophet (ﷺ) did not return the salutation to him until he performed ablution. He then apologised to him, saying: I disliked remembering Allah except in the state of purification.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) emphasized the importance of cleanliness and purification before engaging in religious acts like greeting. When a man greeted him while urinating, he did not return the salutation until the man performed ablution, signifying the need for proper hygiene and respect for religious practices.

English_Hadith: Narrated A'ishah: The Apostle of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) used to remember Allaah, the Great and Majestic, at all moments.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) demonstrated a deep connection with Allah (SWT) by remembering Him at all times, even during personal activities. This highlights the importance of maintaining a continuous relationship with God and seeking His guidance in all aspects of life.

English_Hadith: Narrated Anas ibn Malik: When the Prophet (ﷺ) entered the privy, he removed his ring.Abu Dawud said: This is a munkar tradition, i.e. it contradicts the well-known version reported by reliable narrators. On the authority of Anas the well-known version says: The Prophet (ﷺ) had a silver ring made for him. Then he cast it off. The misunderstanding is on the part of Hammam (who is the narrator of the previous tradition mentioned in the text). This is transmitted only by Hammam.
Hadith_Expalation: While this hadith is considered weak, it may suggest that the Prophet (PBUH) believed in avoiding unnecessary adornments during personal activities. This could be interpreted as a form of modesty or a desire to focus on the spiritual aspects of life.

English_Hadith: Narrated Ibn 'Abbas : The Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) passed by two graves. He said : Both (the dead) are being punished, but they are not being punished for a major (sin). One did not safeguard himself from urine. The other carried tales. He then called for a fresh twig and split it into two partsand planted one part on each grave and said: Perhaps their punishment may be mitigated as long as the twigs remain fresh.Another version of Hannad has: "One of them did not cover himself while urinating." This version does not have the words: "He did not safeguard himself from urine."
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) warned against the severe consequences of neglecting modesty and proper behavior, even in personal matters. The punishment of two people who were buried for not covering themselves while urinating and carrying tales serves as a stark reminder of the importance of these principles.

English_Hadith: Narrated Ibn 'Abbas: A tradition from the Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) conveyingsimilar meaning.The version of Jarir has the wording : "he did not cover himself while urinating."The version of Abu Mu'awiyah has the wording: "he did not safeguard himself (from urine)."
Hadith_Expalation: Another hadith reinforcing the importance of covering oneself while urinating. This highlights the connection between physical modesty and spiritual well-being.

English_Hadith: Narrated Amr ibn al-'As: AbdurRahman ibn Hasanah reported: I and Amr ibn al-'As went to the Prophet (ﷺ). He came out with a leather shield (in his hand). He covered himself with it and urinated. Then we said: Look at him. He is urinating as a woman does. The Prophet (ﷺ), heard this and said: Do you not know what befell a person from amongst Banu Isra'il (the children of Israel)? When urine fell on them, they would cut off the place where the urine fell;but he (that person) forbade them (to do so), and was punished in his grave.Abu Dawud said: One version of Abu Musa has the wording: "he cut off his skin".Another version of Abu Musa goes: "he cut off (part of) his body."
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) rebuked people for cutting themselves after being urinated on, emphasizing the importance of seeking proper medical treatment and avoiding extreme measures. This demonstrates the Prophet's concern for the physical and spiritual well-being of his followers.

English_Hadith: Narrated Hudhaifah : The Apostle of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) came to a midden of some people and urinated while standing. He then asked for water and wiped his shoes.Abu Dawud said: Musaddad, a narrator, reported: I went far away from him. He then called me and I reached just near his heals.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) demonstrated the importance of cleanliness and hygiene even in personal activities. By urinating while standing and wiping his shoes with water, he set an example for his followers and emphasized the connection between physical cleanliness and spiritual purity.

English_Hadith: Narrated Umaymah daughter of Ruqayqah: The Prophet (ﷺ) had a wooden vessel under his bed in which he would urinate at night.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) used a wooden vessel to urinate at night, highlighting the importance of personal hygiene and avoiding open urination. This practice demonstrates the Prophet's concern for cleanliness and his attention to even the smallest details of daily life.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Hurairah: The Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) as saying : Be on your guard against two things which provoke cursing. They (the hearers) said : Prophet of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam), what are these things which provoke cursing: easing in the watering places and on the thoroughfares, and in the shade (of the tree)(where they take shelter and rest).
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) warned against the harmful effects of urinating in public places like watering places, thoroughfares, and shade. This demonstrates the Prophet's concern for the well-being of others and his emphasis on avoiding actions that could be offensive or harmful.

English_Hadith: Narrated Mu'adh ibn Jabal: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: Be on your guard against three things which provoke cursing: easing in the watering places and on the thoroughfares, and in the shade (of the tree).
Hadith_Expalation: Another hadith reinforcing the prohibition against urinating in watering places, thoroughfares, and shade. This further emphasizes the importance of respecting public spaces and avoiding actions that could be harmful to others.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abdullah ibn Mughaffal: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: No one of you should make water in his bath and then wash himself there (after urination).The version of Ahmad has: Then performs ablution there, for evil thoughts come from it.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) forbade urinating in one's bath and then washing there, as this can lead to evil thoughts. This highlights the connection between physical cleanliness and spiritual purity, as well as the importance of avoiding actions that could compromise one's spiritual well-being.

English_Hadith: Narrated A Man from the Companions: Humayd al-Himyari said: I met a man (Companion of the Prophet) who remained in the company of the Prophet (ﷺ) just as AbuHurayrah remained in his company. He then added: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) forbade that anyone amongst us should comb (his hair) every day or urinate in the place where he takes a bath.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) forbade combing hair every day and urinating in the place where one takes a bath. This demonstrates the Prophet's concern for personal hygiene and his belief in the importance of maintaining a clean and healthy environment.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abdullah ibn Sarjis: The Prophet (ﷺ) prohibited to urinate in a hole.Qatadah (a narrator) was asked about the reason for the disapproval of urinating in a hole. He replied: It is said that these (holes) are the habitats of the jinn.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) prohibited urinating in a hole, as these places are said to be inhabited by jinn. This highlights the Prophet's belief in the spiritual world and his concern for avoiding actions that could potentially harm one's spiritual well-being.

English_Hadith: Narrated Aisha, Ummul Mu'minin: When the Prophet (ﷺ) came out of the privy, he used to say: "Grant me Thy forgiveness."
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) emphasized seeking forgiveness from Allah (SWT) after using the toilet. This highlights the importance of acknowledging God's blessings and seeking His mercy.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Qatadah: The Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam) said: When any one of you urinates, he must not touch his penis with his right hand,and when he goes to relieve himself he must not wipe himself with his right hand (in the privy), and when he drinks, he must not drink in one breath.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) instructed Muslims to avoid using their right hand for certain actions while using the toilet, such as touching the private parts or wiping. This might be due to cultural norms or the use of the right hand for eating and drinking.

English_Hadith: Narrated Hafsah, Ummul Mu'minin: The Prophet (ﷺ) used his right hand for taking his food and drink and used his left hand for other purposes.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) demonstrated the practice of using his right hand for clean activities like eating and drinking, and his left hand for unclean activities like using the toilet. This established a clear distinction for hygiene purposes.

English_Hadith: Narrated Aisha, Ummul Mu'minin: The Prophet (ﷺ) used his right hand for getting water for ablution and taking food, and his left hand for his evacuation and for anything repugnant.
Hadith_Expalation: Another hadith from Aisha (RA) reinforces the concept of using the right hand for clean activities and the left hand for unclean activities.

English_Hadith: Narrated AbuHurayrah: Aishah, also reported a tradition bearing similar meaning through another chain of transmitters.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith narrated by AbuHurayrah (RA) confirms Aisha's (RA) narration about the designated use of hands.

English_Hadith: Narrated AbuHurayrah: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: If anyone applies collyrium, he should do it an odd number of times. If he does so, he has done well; but if not, there is no harm. If anyone cleanses himself with pebbles, he should use an odd number. If he does so, he has done well; but if not, there is no harm.If anyone eats, he should throw away what he removes with a toothpick and swallow what sticks to his tongue. If he does so, he has done well; if not, there is no harm. If anyone goes to relieve himself, he should conceal himself, and if all he can do is to collect a heap of send, he should sit with his back to it, for the devil makes sport with the posteriors of the children of Adam. If he does so, he has done well; but if not, there is no harm.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) provided guidance on various aspects of using the toilet. This includes using an odd number of pebbles for cleansing, concealing oneself, and avoiding sitting directly facing the wind. These practices promote hygiene, modesty, and respect for the privacy of others.

English_Hadith: Narrated Ruwayfi' ibn Thabit: Shayban al-Qatbani reported that Maslamah ibn Mukhallad made Ruwayfi' ibn Thabit the governor of the lower parts (of Egypt). He added: We travelled with him from Kum Sharik to Alqamah or from Alqamah to Kum Sharik (the narrator doubts) for Alqam.Ruwayfi' said: Any one of us would borrow a camel during the lifetime of the Prophet (ﷺ) from the other, on condition that he would give him half the booty, and the other half he would retain himself.Further, one of us received an arrowhead and a feather, and the other an arrow-shaft as a share from the booty.He then reported: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: You may live for a long time after I am gone, Ruwayfi', so, tell people that if anyone ties his beard or wears round his neck a string to ward off the evil eye, or cleanses himself with animal dung or bone, Muhammad has nothing to do with him.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) warned against practices like wearing charms, using animal dung or bone for cleaning, and revealing oneself while using the toilet. This emphasizes the importance of cleanliness, avoiding superstitions, and maintaining modesty.

English_Hadith: This tradition has also been narrated by Abu Salim al-Jaishani on the authority of 'Abd Allaah b. 'Amr. He narrated this tradition at the time when he besieged the fort at the gate of Alyun. Abu Dawud said: The fort of Alyun lies at the mountain in Fustat. Abu Dawud said: The kunyah (surname) of Shaiban b. Umayyah is Abu Hudhaifah.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith narrated by Abu Salim al-Jaishani (RA) confirms the prohibition of practices mentioned in Hadith 37.

English_Hadith: Narrated Jabir b. 'Abd Allaah: The Apostle of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) forbade us to use a bone or dung for wiping.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) explicitly forbade the use of bones and dung for cleaning after using the toilet. This ensures proper hygiene and discourages the use of unclean materials.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abdullah ibn Mas'ud: A deputation of the jinn came to the Prophet (ﷺ) and said: O Muhammad, forbid your community to cleans themselves with a bone or dung or charcoal, for in them Allah has provided sustenance for us.So the Prophet (ﷺ) forbade them to do so.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith narrates a story of jinn requesting the Prophet (PBUH) to ask his followers not to use bones and dung for cleaning, as these were their source of sustenance. The Prophet (PBUH) then prohibited this practice, demonstrating his consideration for all creatures while emphasizing hygiene.

English_Hadith: Narrated Aisha, Ummul Mu'minin: The Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) said: When any of you goes to relieve himself, he should take with him three stones to cleans himself, for they will be enough for him.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) advised using three stones for cleansing after using the toilet, emphasizing the importance of proper hygiene.

English_Hadith: Narrated Khuzaymah ibn Thabit: The Prophet (ﷺ) was asked about cleansing (after relieving oneself). He said: (One should cleanse oneself) with three stones which should be free from dung.Abu Dawud said: A similar tradition has been narrated by Abu Usamah and Ibn Numair from Hisham.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) clarified that the stones used for cleansing should be free from dung, ensuring cleanliness and avoiding contamination.

English_Hadith: Narrated Aisha, Ummul Mu'minin: The Prophet (ﷺ) urinated and Umar was standing behind him with a jug of water. He said: What is this, Umar? He replied: Water for you to perform ablution with. He said: I have not been commanded to perform ablution every time I urinate. If I were to do so, it would become a sunnah.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) clarified that performing ablution after every urination was not obligatory, and doing so would become a sunnah (tradition).

English_Hadith: Narrated Anas b. Malik : The Apostle of Allaah ( sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) entered a park. He was accompanied by a boy who had a jug of water with him. He was the youngest of us. He placed it near the lote-tree. He ( the Prophet, sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) relieved himself. He came to us after he had cleansed himself with water.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith highlights the practice of carrying water for cleansing after using the toilet, demonstrating the importance of personal hygiene and the care taken by companions.

English_Hadith: Narrated AbuHurayrah: The Prophet (ﷺ) said: The following verse was revealed in connection with the people of Quba': "In it are men who love to be purified" (ix.108). He (AbuHurayrah) said: They used to cleanse themselves with water after easing. So the verse was revealed in connection with them.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) linked a Quranic verse about purification with the practice of cleansing with water after using the toilet, emphasizing the importance of hygiene and spiritual purity.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Hurayrah : When the Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) went to the privy, I took to him water in a small vesselor a skin, and he cleansed himself. He then wiped his hand on the ground. I then took to him another vesseland he performed ablution.Abu Dawud said : The tradition is transmitted by al-Aswad b. 'Amir is more perfect.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) used water for cleansing and a toothpick for cleaning his teeth, demonstrating the importance of oral hygiene and overall cleanliness.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Hurayrah : (the Prophet, sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) as saying : Were it not that I might oeverburdern the believers, I would order them to delay the night ('isha ) prayer and use the tooth-stick at the time of every prayer.
Hadith_Expalation: The Prophet (PBUH) expressed his desire to order Muslims to use a toothpick after every prayer but refrained from doing so to avoid burdening them.

English_Hadith: Narrated Zayd ibn Khalid al-Juhani: I heard the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) say: Were it not hard on my ummah, I would order them to use the tooth-stick at the time of every prayer. AbuSalamah said: Zayd ibn Khalid used to attend the prayers in the mosque with his tooth-stick on his ear where a clerk carries a pen, and whenever he got up for prayer he used it.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith highlights the practice of using a toothpick after every prayer, as demonstrated by Zayd ibn Khalid al-Juhani.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abdullah b. 'Abd Allah b. 'Umar: Muhammad ibn Yahya ibn Habban asked Abdullah ibn Abdullah ibn Umar about the reason for Ibn Umar's performing ablution for every prayer, whether he was with or without ablution.He replied: Asma', daughter of Zayd ibn al-Khattab, reported to me that Abdullah ibn Hanzalah ibn AbuAmir narrated to her that the Messenger of Allah (ﷺ) was earlier commanded to perform ablution for every prayer whether or not he was with ablution.When it became a burden for him, he was ordered to use tooth-stick for every prayer. As Ibn Umar thought that he had the strength (to perform the ablution for every prayer), he did not give up performing ablution for every prayer.Abu Dawud said: Ibrahim b. Sa'd narrated this tradition on the authority of Muhammad b. Ishaq, and there he mentions the name of 'Ubaid Allah b. 'Abd Allah (instead of 'Abd Allah b. 'Abd Allah b. 'Umar)
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith provides historical context about the practice of performing ablution for every prayer and the subsequent use of a toothpick when ablution became burdensome.

English_Hadith: Narrated Abu Burdah: On the authority of his father ( Abu Musa al-Ash'ari), reported (according to the version of Musaddad) : We came to the Apostle of Allaah (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam) to provide us with a mount, and found him using the tooth-stick, its one end being at his tongue (i.e. he wsa rinsing his mouth).According to the version of Sulaiman it goes : I entered upon the Prophet (sal Allaahu alayhi wa sallam ) who was using the tooth-stick, and had it placed at one side of his tongue, producing a gurgling sound.Abu Dawud said : Musaddad said that the tradition was a lengthy but he shortened it.
Hadith_Expalation: This hadith describes the Prophet (PBUH) using a toothpick to clean his teeth, emphasizing the importance of oral hygiene and personal care.
